It‚Äôll be surreal to one day take my kids to the Smithsonian and show them the blue suit behind glass. I hope they grow to know the truth of Jan6, but I also hope the story ultimately is one of hope and resilience. I hope that is what they and others see in the blue suit. END http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E5nZYIgXEAQXd2G.jpg

Patriotism isn‚Äôt to think we are infallible; it is to know we make mistakes but to love our nation and one another with care enough to fix the injustices that remain. To know our resilience. To have humility to know that we are a part of something bigger than all of us. 16/17

Smithsonian is entrusted to help tell the story of America. It isn‚Äôt always a pretty story, but it is an unfinished story with the persistent hope that it will improve and that we can repair our faults. More importantly, it is our story. It is shared truth binding us as one.15/17

Instead of trying to erase history they don‚Äôt like after the fact, politicians should just act in a way that doesn‚Äôt produce such shameful results. It‚Äôs not hard to not incite or cover up an insurrection. 14/17

There are those trying to erase what happened, voting against commissions/committees aimed at documenting history. They say just move on and turn the page. But I say, you can‚Äôt turn the page of American history until you write the page first. 13/17 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E5nZGQ7WYAAbXPK.jpg

I told the Smithsonian yes to donating the blue suit because the telling of the story of Jan6 isn‚Äôt optional, it is necessary. There are many stories of Jan6. Mine is just one. We cannot heal as a nation unless we have truth. Let truth be truth. 12/17 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E5nZAZkXIAQqx2B.jpg

The story of that day wasn‚Äôt just destruction. There was hope and resilience. The Capitol Police were heroes that saved lives. Colleagues and staff showed bravery. I hope those stories are told. They help tell a story of light on one of the darkest days in our democracy. 11/17 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E5nY4t7XEAIRZ1z.jpg

When the Smithsonian requested the suit, I tried to imagine what an exhibit about Jan6 would look like. Perhaps it would have broken glass from shattered doors, torn flags and signs. Video of the mob trying to hijack our democracy. But there was so much more to that day. 10/17 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E5nYv4kXIAQJO3G.jpg

The Smithsonian called later in January. Honestly, I wasn‚Äôt thinking about how the day would be remembered as I was still living it. In fact, after the call, I had to pull over on the side of I-95 as I started to tear up uncontrollably while driving home. I was still not ok.9/17

People wrote saying the blue suit gave them a sense of resilience and hope. For me, I was in a tough place. In days after Jan6 I had an unshakable regret that I didn‚Äôt do more to keep people safe. But feeling of hope/resilience in the cards helped me feel stronger. Thank you.8/17 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E5nYY2KWYAMi0xV.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E5nYdh1WUA0MLIT.jpg

In the following days, I started to receive thousands of cards from across the country. Many from kids. Strangers who wanted to tell me how they felt when they saw the photo of me. They talked about the blue suit. The suit meant something different to them than it did to me.7/17 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E5nX-KhXMAISrp6.jpg

When I got home I vowed to never wear the suit again. I even considered throwing it away. It only brought back terrible memories. I could never separate that suit from the events of Jan6. I hid it in my closet as I never wanted to see it again. But then something happened. 6/17 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E5nXggbXwAQATh-.jpg

JANUARY 13: The last time I wore the blue suit wasn‚Äôt Jan 6, it was Jan13. I wore it when I walked onto the House floor to cast my vote for impeachment. The suit still had dust on the knees from Jan6. I wore it so I would have no doubt about the truth of what happened. 5/17 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E5nXaYlXMAM-IvY.jpg

Like my suit, what I did on Jan 6 on its face was unremarkable. I saw a mess and cleaned it. I wanted to right the wrongs of that day as quickly and as tangibly as I could. Neither my suit nor my actions are on their own worthy of memory, but the story didn‚Äôt end there. 4/17 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E5nXU8FXoAcP1x8.jpg

JANUARY 6: I woke with the news of the wins in Georgia. I decided to wear the blue suit. I bought it to be a suit of celebration, and I thought what better way to give the suit meaning than to wear it when I confirm the electoral college and then later to the inauguration. 3/17 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E5nXOF2WQAE7kd9.jpg

STORY OF THE BLUE SUIT: When the Smithsonian asked me to donate the blue suit, I thought about how the suit itself is unremarkable. Bought off-the-rack at JCrew during a holiday sale. I wanted a bright blue new suit to wear to Biden‚Äôs inauguration. Then Jan 6 happened‚Ä¶2/17 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E5nXC6gX0AAIudt.jpg

6 months ago today I wore this blue suit as I cleaned the Capitol after the insurrection, now I just donated it to the Smithsonian. Jan6 must never be forgotten. While some try to erase history, I will fight to tell the story so it never happens again. Here is one story‚Ä¶(THREAD) http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E5nW3h2WYAQwCvN.jpg

‚ÄúAsk not what your country can do for you ‚Äì ask what you can do for your country.‚Äù - John F. Kennedy, 1961

There‚Äôs no question that Donald J. Trump lit this flame. 

But, as we reflect on that wretched day six months later,  never forget that it was Republicans in Congress who handed him the match.

With our own eyes, we saw Trump whip a crowd of his supporters into a frenzy and urge them to march to the Capitol. With our own ears, we heard Rudy Giuliani tell them to engage in a "trial by combat." 

The mob was given orders, and the world watched as they carried them out.

I will not mince words about that nightmare. The siege of the US Capitol was an act of violent insurrection against a coequal branch of the federal government, incited by a president desperate for power and incapable of coping with perceived humiliation or defeat.
Tragically, a rioter pushing her way through that same broken window was shot and killed several moments later.

As we left for a secure location through the Speaker's Lobby, I turned and saw another makeshift barricade had been erected. I looked up and through smashed glass saw a second faction of the mob attempting to force their way onto the floor from the front of the Chamber.

We were evacuated from the Chamber as the mob smashed through the windows and attempted to break down the doors at the main entrance to the floor -- the same doors presidents are ushered through to deliver State of the Union addresses.

Speaker Pelosi and others were rushed off the floor while the Sergeant at Arms locked the chamber doors and instructed members to don the gas masks kept under our seats in case of a chemical attack. With weapons drawn, Capitol Police used furniture to barricade the doors.

On Wednesday, January 6 I arrived at the Capitol for the counting of the Electoral College votes. I was on the House floor when the building was breached and the House Chamber was placed into lockdown.
